text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in the April 17 edition of Russia's Izvestia newspaper. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Russian oil company LUKoil, the biggest shareholder of Izvestia, threatened to establish political censorship after the newspaper criticised Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, which had a negative effect on LUKoil's reputation.
- Russia's prime minister appears reluctant to restructure natural monopolies. The government looks like a mouse trying to hang a bell around cat's neck, the daily says.
- Russian producers are to receive legislative support as part of a protectionist policy proclaimed by President Yeltsin on Tuesday in his weekly radio radio address, the parliament speaker said.
- A woman who the paper says helped free a captured Italian journalist in Chechnya declines to give details of her role.
